item.title: Suicide Attack Kills at Least 13 in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack on Sunday apparently targeted the father of two prominent officials in Nangarhar Province.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel outside the house in Jalalabad that was targeted by a suicide bomber on Sunday morning.

item.title: American Missionary Among the Dead in Burkina Faso Siege
item.description: Michael James Riddering, who moved from Florida, worked at the Les Ailes de Refuge Orphanage, about 70 miles from Ouagadougou.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Among the Captives Freed by Iran, a U.S. Researcher Held for 40 Days
item.description: Matthew Trevithick, in the country to study language, was detained in December, but his arrest wasn’t previously revealed and officials haven’t explained it.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
item.description: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: From left, Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister; Yukiya Amano, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency; and Federica Mogherini, the European Union’s high representative for foreign affairs and security policy, at the meeting in Vienna.

item.title: Iran Frees Americans, Including Jason Rezaian, in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Word of the exchange came just before longstanding economic sanctions on Iran were lifted under terms of the historic nuclear deal reached in July.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERBRINK and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters

item.title: Taiwan’s New Leader Faces a Weak Economy and China’s Might
item.description: Tsai Ing-wen, elected Saturday as Taiwan’s first female president, brings what some call a more calm and rational approach to the island’s turbulent politics.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan’s first female president, after her election victory on Saturday.

item.title: Singer’s Apology for Waving Taiwan Flag Stirs Backlash of Its Own
item.description: The videotaped apology from the singer, Chou Tzu-yu, with the K-pop band Twice, was addressed in a victory speech by Taiwan’s president-elect.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Before Debris Collapse in China, Safety Fears Were Discussed
item.description: China’s industrial safety record has improved in recent years, but the ruling Communist Party still struggles to impose accountability on local bureaucrats.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Firefighters searched for survivors amid the debris of destroyed buildings in Shenzhen, China, on Dec. 21.

item.title: On Paper, Italy Allows Abortions, but Few Doctors Will Perform Them
item.description: For over three decades, the procedure has been legal in the predominantly Catholic nation, but most gynecologists are conscientious objectors.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benedetta scrambled to find a doctor after her gynecologist refused her abortion request.

item.title: Huffington Post Waited to Report U.S.-Iran Prisoner-Swap Negotiations
item.description: The news organization said it chose not to run an article on the negotiations over a prisoner exchange that included a Washington Post reporter, though it learned about the talks last fall.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER
item.media:description: The wife of Saeed Abedini holding a necklace with a photograph of her husband, a pastor who was arrested in Iran in 2012. Iran announced on Saturday that it had released four Iranian-Americans, including Mr. Abedini, as part of a prisoner exchange with the United States.

item.title: Flamboyant Egyptian Politician Craves Public Eye
item.description: For many Egyptians, Mortada Mansour’s behavior has only confirmed their low expectations of the new Parliament, which is weak and heavily tilted in favor of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Pauline Beugnies for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mortada Mansour, center, a lawmaker and lawyer, is on an influential parliamentary committee.

item.title: In Tehran, Iranians Play Down Milestone
item.description: The low-key reception for the expected lifting of sanctions reflects multiple disappointments and broken promises.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Tehran’s Grand Bazaar on Saturday. International sanctions on Iran related to its nuclear activities were expected to be lifted soon.

item.title: Deadly Standoff Leaves Burkina Faso Stunned
item.description: Gunfire raged through the night as armed forces from Burkina Faso, assisted by French and American forces, stormed the popular downtown area where attackers had set off explosives.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Rescue workers carrying a body from the Splendid Hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Saturday.

item.title: Q. and A.: What Happens Now That Sanctions Are Lifted?
item.description: The most immediate benefit to Iran will be access to roughly $100 billion of its own money, but the United States still has a raft of sanctions in place.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
item.description: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters

item.title: Leonid Zhabotinsky, Strongman for the Ages, Dies at 77
item.description: The Big Zhabo, as he was known, set his first of 19 world superheavyweight weight-lifting records in 1963.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Leonid Zhabotinsky, center, after winning a gold medal at the Summer Games in Tokyo in 1964.

item.title: Kuwait Airways Drops Flights to Avoid Israeli Passengers
item.description: Instead of stopping the practice of blocking Israeli passengers from traveling between New York City and London, as the Transportation Department requested, the airline canceled the flights.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Kuwait Airways will cease flights between New York City and London, deciding to drop the route rather than transport Israeli citizens between the two cities.

item.title: Profiles of Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmat and Jason Rezaian
item.description: Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmat and Jason Rezaian are among the American citizens who have been held in Iran.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, Saeed Abedini and Amir Hekmati

item.title: Tsai Ing-wen Elected President of Taiwan, First Woman to Hold Office
item.description: Voters were expected to give Ms. Tsai’s Democratic Progressive Party control of the legislature, giving her broad authority to push her policies in office.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen arriving at a polling station Saturday to cast her ballot.

item.title: Sean Penn Says His El Chapo Article ‘Has Failed’
item.description: In an interview with CBS to be broadcast on Sunday, Mr. Penn said he had hoped that his interview with the fugitive would lead to a debate about the drug war.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sean Penn at an event he put on to raise money for the Haitian Relief Organization on Saturday. He spoke with CBS on Thursday about his meeting with the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera.
